I have a BS in Physics, and only after a transferred to a uni which had changed to the Paradigm/Capstone sequence, you know, the one which asks the students what they think and why they think that way, did I actually learn physics. We learned that it was a self balancing, nuanced, fascinating field. But only if you had a department that cared more about teaching than chasing ever dwindling amounts of research money.

And, just to let you know, if you're thinking graduate school is what you should do, I would suggest that you wander over to a public uni, because there are far more of them than prestigious private ones. Find out the % of current faculty that are adjunct, assistant, associate and full professor. See if any of the bastards who run the joint will tell you of their current Tenure Track faculty openings. Find out what happens to your research in case your denied tenure, i.e., fired, and if any of it belongs to you. Ask what their current policy is regarding the curriculum that you set up, you know, all the work that you put into creating the notes, tests, annotations, all of the things required to actually teach the god damn subject. Then make sure that you know the unemployment policies in the state which you have taken on the post doc serfdom that you decided was the way to spend about 5-8 years of the most highly productive period of your life. Reason being that TTF is rapidly going away, the chances of you becoming tenured are far, far less than you ever being anything above an associate prof, and that the chances are far, far greater that you will be asked to leave, and not come back, no matter how smart or hard working you've proven to be.

Reality is, STEM departments are overflowing with untenured profs who will never get the brass ring. They will be stuck doing useless research, writing articles for third rate journals which are read by two people, and hoping upon hope that TPTB will leave them alone when the next wave of firings take place, which they will increasingly be happening. OP is cute, and somewhat funny, but truth to tell, some of it is bullshit. With H-1B/L visas, if they want to get anyone to do STEM work, they can yank someone from China/India, who is as smart, if not smarter, but desperate for work, and have them do the work for about 1/3 less than you're bottom line pay.

There are 2 fields I feel are worth mentioning that you didn't touch on.  While economics wouldn't count as something where you would apply physics directly, it would use the math skills you've been building up.  Several Universities find that all of the physics and astrophysics grad students have informal interviews with wall street companies.  Several banks and investment companies prefer to hire people with a physics background than an economic background.  The reason is simple: in economics you are taught the math that they expect you to encounter as an economist, but in physics you are taught to select the best mathematical technique to solve a problem in the physical world.  This is often even better than a pure math degree, where you are taught to develop new mathematical techniques, more than anything else.
    A second field would be law.  Given that patents have been awarded in some countries for nothing more than the wheel, we need lawyers with a background in physics to prevent some of this silliness.  Also, in law they will often argue that law applies to everything, but physics is still special, since it has that in common with law.  In other words, physics is the study of everything in the Universe and how it works, law is the set of rules for human behaviour in everyting there could be conflict, so both fields have this 'we do everything' mentality.
    Lastly, physics gets a lot of spill-over funding from engineering, as biology gets a lot of spill-over funding from medicine.  Far fewer people go into medical physics than bio-engineering, so medical physics is the best place to rake in the dollars.  If you wouldn't be satisfied with a pure researcher's (either academic or in industry, don't forget) salary (one of the highest paid non-medical professions out there, gosh you have high standards), then consider this: in the four years I worked on my bachelor's degree, every single graduate that even considered doing graduate studies in the same city had the option of making six figures (it would also be six figures in US currency, I'm not from the US) WHILE pursuing a Master's degree.  That is what the job market for medical physics looks like.
